content.description: Wide crack with a tree and Boulder in front of it. Climb up onto Boulder, place your one piece and step across into the wide crack. Shimmy and bump your way to the top!
content.protection: You can bump a 6 to the top!
content.location: On the opposite side of the Boulder with the two sport routes on it. There is a tree and some bushes in front of the start. You can’t miss the climb.

content.description: Awesome slab moves, not your typical high step and crimp route! Really fun finish, can hang left or right to the anchors and find a different experience!
content.location: Locate the tombstone. Furthest left bolted line on the east face!

content.description: Squeeze chimney/offwidth. I went up on this one in a yoga frog pose from the beginning to the chockstone. From on top of the chockstone follow the chimney to the top or if you have a #7 follow the crack on the left.
content.protection: I think I bumped a #5 to the chockstone. At the top there are no rappel anchors yet (coming soon) but you can use the sport routes on the south side  carefully or do a sketchy downclimb on the west side.

content.location: South face left of the obvious large crack

climbs.name: Don't Hit the Ledges!
climbs.fa: Open Project. Has been toproped clean.

content.description: If you stitch the route to stay off the ledges and have a good belayer I think this route should be PG but I have not led it yet, just top roped it. The route is basically a hard slab for your feet and a finger crack for your hands with a V4 boulder problem nicely protected with a bolt. A pretty unique type of climbing.
content.protection: Mostly small gear, 0.1-0.75 and one quickdraw for the crux bolt. Top rope/belay by building an anchor with gear and the tree at the end of the route.

content.description: The right crack start goes at 5.7 and the left crack start at 5.9. The 5.9 joins the 5.7 whenever you can make the transition.
Widening crack. The crux is probably topping out.
content.protection: Cams from #1 to #7. FA was done with just a #6 but a fall at the end would have been bad. If no #7 you could protect the last bolt of the sport route left of the crack.

content.description: Most of the routes are on the large boulder west of the Tombstone -- there is only one aid route on the actual Tombstone. There are routes facing south, east, west, and north, which allows for some climbing in any weather.
